conclusion: The triangle has vertices A, B, C, and side length BC = L. Light parallel to BC is incident on AB, only light in BD can enter the hemisphere. Length of BD = L/4.
The hemisphere has its center at O, and refracted light propagates within the hemisphere.
The longest propagation time corresponds to the longest path that refracted light can travel within the hemisphere, entering at D and exiting at the farthest point.
Refracted light enters the hemisphere at D and travels along the chord x of the hemisphere. Angle of incidence at D is theta, refracted light travels at angle 30Â° - theta relative to horizontal.
The longest chord in a hemisphere is the diameter, which is equal to L, the side length of BC.
The longest path x that refracted light can travel is equal to the diameter of the hemisphere, x = L.
Propagation speed of light in vacuum is c.
Assuming refracted light travels at speed c within the hemisphere, propagation time t is given by t = Path length / Speed.
For the longest path x = L, the propagation time is t = L/c.
The longest propagation time of refracted light in the hemisphere is t = L/c.
